title: Responsive design with Bootstrap
author: Niklas Würfl
description:
Responsive design is an approach to web design that ensures a website is optimized for all devices and screen sizes. This is achieved by creating a flexible and adaptable layout that adjusts based on the screen size and orientation of the device being used. Bootstrap is a popular framework for building responsive websites, and it provides a range of pre-built classes that can be used to create responsive layouts quickly and easily.

Bootstrap provides a set of grid classes that allow web developers to create responsive layouts that adjust based on the device's screen size. It is based on HTML, CSS, and JavaScript including pre-designed templates, components, and utilities. With these, a professional-looking website can be designed. It provides numerous ready-to-go components and styles, so that a responsive web application can be built very easily.

The bootstrap grid is based on a 12-column system, and web developers can choose the number of columns a particular element should occupy at a given screen size. For example, the 'col-sm-6' class can be used to specify that an element should occupy six columns on small screens, and the remaining six columns should be left blank. This provides flexibility and ensures that the layout is optimized for all screen sizes.

In addition to the grid system, Bootstrap provides a range of other classes that can be used to style and format elements on a web page. For example, we can set the background of an element to black with the class “bg-black”, add padding to an element with “p-3” or change text to a bold text by adding the class “font-weight-bold”.

Bootstrap can be customized as well. Variables can be defined manually, by for example overriding the primary and secondary colour with an own colour of choice. This way, a design following the own taste or requirements can be achieved.

Using bootstrap, can save time when comparing to creating a similar design using only CSS.

title: HTML - an introduction
author: Niklas Würfl
description:
HTML could be called something like the basis of the Internet. Each web page is generated by HTML and this language makes it possible to display information in browsers easily.

Being a markup language, HTML is only there to display information, not to fulfill logical or computational tasks. It uses a series of tags to define and format text, images, videos, and other elements on a webpage. These tags are enclosed in angle brackets (<>) and contain information about the content they define.

One of the primary reasons to use HTML is that it provides a standardized way to create web pages that can be accessed by anyone with an internet connection. It is compatible with most web browsers, making it easy to create web pages that can be viewed on any device.

HTML also allows us to create accessible websites. Its various tags like headings, lists, tables, and other elements make it easier for people with disabilities to navigate and understand the content on a website. By using these tags, web developers can ensure that their websites are accessible to as many people as possible.

HTML elements can have attributes that reveal further details about the element. For example, the IMG element provides the attributes src, alt, width, and height. With the attributes the details about the displayed picture can be setup and changed.

HTML also allows for the creation of dynamic web pages that can be updated and modified in real-time. By using JavaScript and other web technologies, developers can create interactive web pages that respond to user input and provide a more engaging user experience. This is particularly useful for websites that require user input or provide real-time data, such as social media platforms, e-commerce sites, and news websites.

In summary, HTML is a very important language to create websites, especially when combined with CSS and JavaScript, in order to create user-friendly websites.

title: CSS - an introduction
author: Niklas Würfl
description:
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a style sheet language, with which presentation and layout of a web page can be modified. With CSS, web developers can control the entire visible of a webpage. Layout, typography, color, and more can be adjusted, not dependend from its content.

One of the major advantages of CSS is that it allows for the separation of presentation and content, which makes it easier to maintain and update a website. By separating the visual elements of a web page from its content, changes can be made to the layout, color scheme, and typography efficiently, without having to modify the underlying HTML code.

CSS works by picking out specific HTML elements and modifying the style of them. There are different ways to select an element. Selectors can be used by accessing the class, ID, tag, or attribute of an element. Then, a variety of styles, such as background colors, text sizes, margins, borders, and much more can be applied to the selected elements.

An important concept of CSS is cascading. Styles are applied in a specific order. Depending on the number and types of selectors, a selector specificity is defined. Inline styles and ID-selectors will be applied with a higher priority as class- and tag-selectors. If there is multiple selectors of the same type for an element, the most recently defined rule will be applied to the object.

Another relevant CSS technique is Layout. There are various ways to arrange contents, including the use of floats, flexbox, and grid. Floats are used to arrange items horizontally, while flexbox and grid make more complex layouts possible.

CSS also provides cross-browser compatibility, ensuring that a website looks consistent and functions correctly across different web browsers and devices. This is particularly important in today's world where users access the web from a variety of devices and platforms, including desktop computers, laptops, tablets, and smartphones. No matter on which device, a webpage is viewed, with CSS a seamless user experience can be created.

In conjunction with HTML and JavaScript CSS can create modern, dynamic, and visually appealing web pages.
